"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Summarized chunk:
The Congress finds that the HIV/AIDS epidemic is predicted to become the worst infectious disease in history, surpassing past deadly outbreaks like the bubonic plague and the 1918-1919 influenza epidemic. The gap in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries is widening, jeopardizing progress in child health. The HIV/AIDS epidemic is projected to become the worst infectious disease in history, surpassing past deadly outbreaks like the bubonic plague and the 1918-1919 influenza epidemic. The gap in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries is widening, threatening progress in child health. The HIV/AIDS epidemic is projected to worsen child survival in developing countries, with UNAIDS predicting a potential 100% increase in child mortality by 2010. The National Intelligence Council estimates a threefold increase in AIDS orphans worldwide in the next 10 years, leading to economic decay, social fragmentation, and political destabilization in vulnerable societies. The National Intelligence Council predicts a significant increase in AIDS orphans globally in the next decade, leading to economic decay, social fragmentation, and political destabilization in vulnerable societies. This could result in children being drawn into negative activities like prostitution, crime, substance abuse, or child soldiery. The economic costs of infectious diseases, especially HIV/AIDS, could reduce gross domestic product by 20 percent or more by 2010 in some sub-Saharan African nations. Despite discouraging statistics on HIV/AIDS spread, some developing nations like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have implemented successful prevention programs. Some developing nations like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have implemented successful prevention programs for HIV/AIDS, which could reduce GDP by 20% in some sub-Saharan African nations by 2010. United States financial support for medical research and disease containment has benefits for all Americans. Thailand, Uganda, and Senegal have implemented successful HIV prevention programs, reducing infection rates. United States financial support for global medical research and disease containment benefits all Americans. Contributing to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria is crucial in combating infectious diseases worldwide. In September 1997, the international community endorsed the proposed Fourth Amendment to allocate Special Drawing Rights to combat AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. However, the Executive Branch has not requested Congressional approval for the United States to participate in this initiative. The international community endorsed the proposed Fourth Amendment in September 1997 to combat AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act is amended to accept the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the Fund and contribute Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The United States Governor of the Fund accepts the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement. The Secretary of the Treasury is instructed to seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold special drawing rights. The Secretary of the Treasury is instructed to seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights, contributing to the fight against AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The Secretary of the Treasury is instructed to seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights, contributing to the fight against AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria by providing a portion of the received funds in fiscal years 2004 through 2006. The Secretary of the Treasury is directed to negotiate with other countries to encourage contributions to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria using Special Drawing Rights allocated in fiscal years 2004 through 2006.
